Procurement : The main civil works (such as the main

Consultant Services

About 39 man-months of foreign and 77
man-months of local consultant services
will be required in the following
fields: (i) irrigation design and
planning; (ii) construction management;
(iii) irrigation system design; (iv)

(vi) others. Foreign consultant
services are required to complement the

consultants will be recruited in

Project Benefits : The Project will result in an increase
in agriculture output (of an estimated
$4.7 million annually at 1991 constant
prices) through (i) a modest increase

 (iv)

in irrigated area; (ii) improved yields
arising from enhanced irrigation water
control; and (iii) an increase in
cropping intensity arising from the
earlier availability of irrigation
supplies. The Project will reduce the
O&M requirements of the irrigation
system through (i) replacement of
maintenance-intensive temporary
structures by durable masonry and
concrete ones; and (ii) unification of
the existing six irrigation intakes into
one common structure. The Project will
result in a considerable saving of
forest products which are currently used
to construct and repair timber and
brushwood structures throughout the six
irrigation systems.

LAP:NEP 22126 of October 1991.

 REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION OF THE PRESIDENT
TO THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS ON A PROPOSED LOAN
AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE GRANT
TO ThE KINGDOM OF NEPAL
FOR THE RAJAPUR IRRIGATION REHABILITATION PROJECT

1.
I submit to the Board of Directors, for its consideration and
decision, the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed loan from
the Special Funds resources of the Bank in an amount in various currencies
equivalent to Special Drawing Rights Twelve Million One Hundred Fifty-
Two Thousand ($ 16 . 62 million equivalent) applied for by the Kingdom of
Nepal for the Rajapur Irrigation Rehabilitation Project. The loan will
have a term of 40 years, including a grace period of 10 years and a
service charge of 1 per cent per annum. The Government has also requested
a technical assistance grant, in an amount of $650,000 from the Bank's
Technical Assistance Special Fund, for institutional strengthening of
farmers' associations.

2.
The Government attaches high priority to the Project, which is
also supported by all major donors to the irrigation subsector in Nepal.
In December 1988 the Bank approved a project preparatory technical
assistance ]/ to undertake a feasibility study of the proposed Project.
The consultants stayed in the Project area for nearly six months and
consulted/interacted with the farmers intensively, and incorporated their
felt needs and preferences in their report. The study was completed in
September 1990 and confirmed the viability of the Project. A special task
force of the Department of Irrigation visited the Project area in December
1990 to discuss the recommendations of the consultants with the farmers.
A Fact-Finding Mission visited Nepal in January/February 1991 and had
further consultations with the farmers on the design and scope of the
Project. Subsequently, an Appraisal Mission visited Nepal during April
1991 and confirmed that the Project was consistent with the Government's
sectoral objectives and policies, and also in accordance with the Bank's
operational strategy for Nepal, and was thus suitable for Bank financing.
Formal loan negotiations with authorized representatives of the Government
and Executing Agency were held in Manila on 1 October 1991. If approved,
the loan will be the sixty-eighth to the Kingdom of Nepal, and the twelfth
to the irrigation subsector.

I. THE ECONOMY

3.
A Board Information Paper entitled "Nepal: Economic Review and
Bank Operations" (EBO:NEP 91012) was circulated to the Board on 1 August
1991.	

(DOG. IN. 152-91)

1/ TA No. 1O98-NEP(SF), approved on 29 December 1988 in an amount of

$456,000.

 A. Agriculture Sector

1. Overview

Nepal's economy is predominantly agricultural. Agriculture
4.
contributes about 54 per cent to the gross domestic product; employs about
91 per cent of the economically active population, most of whom are
extremely poor; and provides for over 60 per cent of the exports of the
country. Even the country's nascent industrial sector is heavily
dependent on agriculture for both the supply of raw materials and markets
for finished industrial products. With about 93 per cent of the
population living in rural areas and depending largely on agriculture,
agriculture exercises an all-pervading effect on the socioeconomic life
of the people in Nepal. Because of the overwhelming weight of agriculture
in the national economy, substantial improvements in the people's life,
including the satisfaction of their basic needs, will be possible only
with a significant improvement in this sector. It is, in short, the
agriculture sector that sets the pace for growth in the economy.

Nepal is a rugged and mountainous country with very limited
5.
natural resources. Of its total land area (14.7 million ha) only about
18 per cent (2.6 million ha) is under cultivation; of this, just about one
third has irrigation facilities. Because of Nepal's extremely difficult
topography, significant regional variations exist in agricultural output.
Of the total cultivated area 49 per cent is in the Terai, with the
remainder in the Hills. The majority of the country's agricultural
population consist of small- to medium-scale farmers working on farms of
0.25 ha to 2.0 ha in size. Paddy is the main foodgrain grown on more than
half of the cultivated area. Other major foodgrains are maize, wheat,
barley and millet. Major cash crops are sugarcane, potato, pulses,
oilseeds, jute and tobacco. The very modest 2.4 per cent of overall
annual growth rate of agricultural production, over the period FY1975 to
FY1990, is a cause of great concern. In fact, considering population grew
over the same period at the rate of 2.6 per cent per annum, this implies
a declining per capita food availability. Although in some areas yields
increased as a result of the provision of new  or improved irrigation
facilities and improved agricultural support services, average crop yields
overall either declined or stagnated over this period. Cropping
intensities remained low, at about 125 per cent. The main reasons for the
low yields are that (i) irrigation covers only about 30 per cent of the
cultivated area; (ii) chemical fertilizer use is low at 14 kg/ha; (iii)
agricultural support services are generally inadequate; and (iv) soil
fertility is declining because of erosion, particularly in the Hills. As
the cultivable land cannot be expanded, there is an urgent need to
increase the productivity of existing land (especially in the Terai)
through improved irrigation facilities and availability of modern
agricultural inputs (such as pesticides, improved seeds, chemical
fertilizers, and credit). Within this framework, the intensification of
agriculture by fuller exploitation of existing irrigation facilities is
particularly attractive in view of its cost effectiveness and quick
returns.

 'I

2. Irrigation Subsector

Given the high population growth and modest gains achieved so far
6.
in agricultural production, the enhancement of irrigation facilities as
a means to raising agriculture productivity represents one of the best
opportunities and, therefore, a top priority in the Government's strategy
for development. Government agencies have been involved from the mid-
l960s in the construction, management and enhancement of irrigation
schemes and in assisting farmers to construct and/or rehabilitate private
farmer-managed irrigation schemes (FMISs), and gains have been made. The
main role has been played by the Department of Irrigation (DOl), which has
constructed medium- and large-sized irrigation facilities. The
Agricultural Development Bank of Nepal, has been involved in promoting and
financing, through its agricultural credit operations, the development of
shallow tubewells and small (usually less than 50 ha) surface irrigation
schemes.

At present, about 933,000 ha or 31 per cent of the net cultivated
7.
area has some kind of irrigation facilities. Of these, only about 28 per
cent (covering around 265,000 ha) are DOl-managed facilities, while the
rest (about 668,000 ha) are farmer-managed. Because of the technical
complexity and high cost of irrigation facilities, external assistance to
the irrigation subsector in the past two decades (which amounted to over
$400 million) was mainly directed at the medium- and large-scale schemes
managed by DOl. To date, DOI has constructed 210 irrigation projects (10
large- and 200 medium-scale projects). The performance of these projects,
however, has not been fully satisfactory. Of the total net command area
of about 265,000 ha, it is estimated that only 60 per cent receives
reliable supplementary irrigation during the wet season and 21 per cent
during the dry season. Major factors contributing to this low performance
are: (i) poor operation and maintenance (O&M) partly due to insufficiency
of funds; (ii) inadequate project management and lack of farmer
participation in water management; and (iii) low level of agricultural
support services.

The FMISs have a better performance record, although the
8.
technical problems they are incurring call for some Government
intervention. Of crucial importance is that farmers mobilize their own
resources for O&M without expecting any support from Government agencies.
In so doing, farmers have developed a proprietary interest in the
irrigation scheme, which implies two main advantages: (i) continuous
maintenance of the facilities by the farmers themselves, and (ii) the
absence of any burden on the Government's budget.

Although promising, these schemes face increasing problems, which
9.
have undermined their reliability. Since FMISs are a result of joint
planning, design, construction and management efforts of farmer
groups/communities, technologies and materials used for the construction
and maintenance are generally simple and cheap, reflecting the limited
technical expertise and resources of the farmers. As a result, the canal

 4

systems are rudimentary, lack permanent structures and need constant
maintenance and tedious rehabilitation after each major flood.
Mobilization of free labor, which makes up the bulk of the required
resources, has also become increasingly difficult as many farmers take up
jobs during the agricultural slack period. In addition, timber and
brushwood from the forests, used for the construction and repair of the
irrigation structures, have become increasingly scarce as a result of
deforestation of the nearby catchment areas.

10. In these circumstances, although the main thrust of FMISs remains
valid, there is scope for improving them through the provision of
permanent, properly designed structures, distribution systems and cross
drainage. This, in turn, could expand their command areas and reduce 0&M
costs to a manageable level. It is important, however, in designing the
projects that Government intervention be conceived as a special action
aimed at providing capital and technical assistance to the schemes without
altering their management and farmer-owned features, which represent in
fact their main strength.

B. Government Strategies and Programs for the Irrigation Subsector

11. In recognition of the potential of FMISs to help increase
agricultural production, the Government in August 1988 provided guidelines
in the New Working Policy on Irrigation Develo pment for its assistance to
such schemes. The main features of the new policy are: (i) participation
of farmer beneficiaries in the identification, design, construction and
0&M of new irrigation facilities; and (ii) sharing of construction costs
between the Government and the farmer beneficiaries. In support of this
policy, the Bank approved an Irrigation Sector Loan  j/ for construction
and rehabilitation of small-and medium-sized FMISs. In view of the
institutional capacity of FMISs to take full responsibility for 0&M, the
rehabilitation of such FMISs is considered one of the most cost-effective
investments in irrigation development. The provision of permanent
structures will lead to a more reliable and equitable water distribution
system and will reduce the need to mobilize large amounts of labor. In
addition, the replacement of timber and brushwood structures will reduce
dependency on forest products and the progressive deforestation of the
watershed.

C.	

External Assistance to the Irrigation Subsector

12. Among the external aid agencies, the Bank and the World Bank have
been the major sources of assistance to the irrigation subsector. The
World Bank has provided 11 loans for a total of $ 252.0 million. Other
external donors in the subsector are European Economic Community, India,
Japan, Saudi Arabia, Switzerland, United Nations Children's Fund and

1/	

Loan No. 923-NEP(SF) approved 22 November 1988 in the amount of $36.3
million.

 5

United States.	
irrigation sector is provided in the Appendix.

An illustrative list of external assistance to the

D. Bank Assistance to the Irrigation Subsector

13. Since 1971, the Bank has provided 11 loans to finance seven
irrigation projects in Nepal amounting to a total of $136.3 million. The
Project Performance Audit Report for the Kankai Irrigation Project was
prepared in August 1988. The report concluded that the Project had
generally achieved its physical targets though incurring considerable time
and cost overruns. Project Completion Reports have been circulated to the
Board for the Chitwan Valley Development Project, the First Hill
Irrigation Project and the Command Area Development Project, completed in
1988, 1989 and 1990 respectively. The Chitwan Valley Development Project
was affected by major technical problems during its implementation and was
unsuccessful. The other two projects were generally successful, although
delays were experienced in their implementation.

II. BANK OPERATIONS IN NEPAL

A Board Information Paper "Nepal: Economic Review and Bank
14.
Operations" (EBO:NEP 91012) was circulated to the Board on 1 August 1991.
(DOC. IN.152-91)

Operational Strategy

The Bank's operational strategy for Nepal essentially calls for
15.
the Bank to concentrate its efforts in four areas, namely: (i) seeking
growth in agriculture through improvements in agricultural productivity;
(ii) containment of ecological factors threatening the future productivity
of agriculture (principally through environmental protection measures,
including reforestation, watershed protection and mitigation of soil
erosion); (iii) enhancement of industrial development, in particular
through increased private sector involvement; and (iv) development of
supporting physical and social infrastructure. In conjunction with
concentrating lending activities in these areas, the strategy also calls
for the Bank to support efforts at institution building as well as sector
work on selected institutions and key policies. In addition, it calls for
the Bank to give priority towards alleviating binding constraints and
critical bottlenecks to development and meeting basic needs.

Since Nepal is highly dependent on agriculture, support for
16.
agricultural development is a prominent feature of the Bank's operational
strategy in Nepal. The Bank's efforts in the sector have been mainly
directed at enhancing food production and diversification in cash crops,
horticulture and animal husbandry. This entails intensification of
agriculture (thereby leading to improvements in productivity) in the Terai
and selected Hill areas by fuller exploitation of existing irrigation
facilities, selective expansion of irrigation, improving the effectiveness

 6

of support services and ensuring the availability of key inputs including
research, extension, credit and fertilizer. The Bank's operational
strategy for Nepal recognizes the need for direct assistance to alleviate
poverty, especially among the rural poor. The proposed Project, being
directed as it is towards the enhancement of irrigation facilities,
smallholder agriculture development and poverty alleviation, is therefore
consistent with the Bank's country and sectoral strategy. In particular,
the proposed Project is essentially a continuation of the Bank's
involvement in FMISs under the ongoing Irrigation Sector Loan for small-

and medium-sized schemes.

III. THE PROJECT

17.
A Report entitled "Appraisal of the Rajapur Irrigation
Rehabilitation Project" (Report No. LAP:NEP 22126) is circulated herewith.

A.	

Objectives. Scope and Description

The main objective of the proposed Project is to bring
18.
sustainable development to the Project area. This is to be achieved
through (1) increasing agricultural production and farm incomes through
irrigation improvement, (ii) arresting the loss of irrigated land caused
by river capture and river bank erosion, (iii) reducing environmental
degradation through a reduction of farmers' reliance on forest products
for the repair of their irrigation system, and (iv) strengthening the
institutional base and technical capabilities of the existing farmer
associations. In view of its location in an economically depressed area
of Nepal, the Project will also address the issue of poverty alleviation
for the farmers.

19.
Under the Project, six existing irrigation systems will be
rehabilitated, improved and consolidated in one scheme. In particular,
the Project comprises: (i) replacement of the temporary intake for the
Budi Kulo irrigation system by an ungated permanent structure capable of
restricting the discharge into the system at high flood levels; the
remaining five intakes will be closed and their irrigation system will be
connected to the Budi Kulo main canal, concentrating future maintenance
on one location only, (ii) replacement of the brushwood and boulder weirs
with three concrete weirs to ensure reliable irrigation supplies to the
branch canals, (iii) improvement of the branch canal structures to ensure
delivery of irrigation supplies to the village canals, (iv) upgrading of
37.5 km of service roads to improve farmers' access to major market
centers and to facilitate O&M of the irrigation facilities, and (v)
consultant services for Project implementation to assist in the
preparation of tender documents and in construction design and
supervision. In addition, an advisory technical assistance will be
provided to strengthen the existing farmer associations and to facilitate
their active participation in the Project.

 7

B. Cost Estimates and Financing Arrangements

20.
The total cost of the Project is estimated at $20.72 million
equivalent, of which $10.43 million (50 per cent) represents direct and
indirect foreign exchange costs. The local currency costs, including
taxes and duties, amount to $10.29 million equivalent. The cost estimates
include provision for physical contingencies and price escalation.

21.
It is proposed that the Bank provide a loan of $16.62 million
from its Special Funds resources on standard ADF terms to finance the
entire foreign exchange cost and part of the local currency cost ($6.19
million equivalent). Overall, the Bank would finance about 80 per cent of
the total cost of the Project. The rest of the resources required for the
Project will be contributed by the Government (11 per cent) and the
participating farmers (9 per cent). In providing financing for local
cost, it is relevant to note that the country is making significant
efforts to mobilize domestic resources and to generate savings to support
its development efforts. However, the financial requirements of its
development program are straining available resources as reflected in the
country's continuing saving-investment gap and precarious balance of
payments position.

C. Executing Agency

22. The DOl under the Ministry of Water Resources will be the
Executing Agency for the Project. DOl is familiar with the concept of
farmer participation in the implementation of irrigation projects and is
applying this concept in the ongoing Bank-financed Irrigation Sector
Project (para. 11) and the World Bank-financed Irrigation Line of Credit
Project for small- and medium-sized projects. On the basis of this
performance, DOI is considered capable of and committed to implementing
the Project through the concept of farmers' participation.

D. Imp lementation Arrangements

23. DOI will appoint a Project Manager and provide a core of key
staff who are familiar with the various aspects of farmer participation
in the construction of irrigation projects. The Project Manager will be
responsible for the day-to-day management of the Project and will reside
in the Project office in Rajapur. The Regional Director of the Mid-
Western Irrigation Directorate will be designated the Project Director.
He will be responsible for liaison and coordination between the Project
and the DOI head office in Kathniandu and will have decision-making
authority on most technical and financial matters on behalf of DOI.
During the construction season, he will visit the Project site/area at
least once a month to monitor and discuss with the Project Manager the
progress of Project implementation. Moreover, DOI will establish a
Project Management Committee (PMC) in which it will share responsibility
for Project implementation with a majority representation of the farmers.
The Project Manager will be the Chairman of the PMC, and his deputy will

 8

be the PMC Secretary. The Vice-Chairman of the PMC will be the elected
head of the Executive Committee (Central Farmers Committee or CFC) of the
new Central Farmers Association (CFA, see para. 24). A district
irrigation engineer and not more than seven members of the CFC will serve
as PMC members. The PMC will serve as an active foruw for DOl officials
and farmers to reach a consensus on selected Project matters, and to
exchange information on all other Project matters.

24. Additionally, to ensure the farmers' effective involvement in
Project implementation, DOl is assisting them to establish a new CFA and
its executive committee (the CFC). DOl will also assist in registering
the CFA under the Association Registration Act 2034 in order to formalize
farmers' decisions and agreement with DOl on the following matters: (1)
acceptability of the general scope of works; (ii) future allocation of the
irrigation flow in the main canal among the branch canals; (iii)
organization and resource mobilization (labor and cash) for the O&M; and
(iv) farmers' commitment regarding their contribution to the construction
costs (labor and/or cash).

E.	

Procurement

25. Civil works to be financed by the Bank will be undertaken in
accordance with the Bank's Guidelines for Procurement. Main civil works
(intake structures, weirs and associated offtake, flood embankment,
connecting canals, feeder road) will be undertaken on the basis of
international competitive bidding. The remaining civil works (improvement
of branch canals and village roads, construction of buildings), which will
be simple and dispersed widely over the Project area, will be carried out
under either local competitive bidding, force account, petty contracts or
volunteer labor.

F.	

Consultant Services for Project Implementation

26.
About 39 man-months of foreign and 77 man-months of local
consultant services will be required in the following fields: (i)
irrigation design and planning; (ii) construction management; (iii)
irrigation system design; (iv) road design; (v) river hydraulics; and (vi)
others. Foreign consultant services are required to complement the
services of the local consultants in those fields for which local
expertise is limited (planning, construction management and river
hydraulics). The consultants will be recruited in accordance with the
Bank's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.

C. Accounts. Audits and Reports

27.
The DOl will establish and maintain separate Project accounts for
expenditures on the goods and services to be financed out of the loan
proceeds. Accounts will be audited annually by the Auditor General of the
Borrower, and copies of audit reports will be submitted to the Bank within
12 months after the end of each fiscal year. DOl will also submit to the
Bank (i) trimester progress reports on the status of Project

 9

implementation within two months after the period concerned, (ii) annual
planning reports including a brief assessment of the physical and
financial status of Project implementation for the year, and a detailed
implementation schedule and summary of the budget allocation to be made
for the Project for the subsequent year, (iii) a Project Completion Report
within three months of the completion of the Project, and (iv) annual
inspection reports after completion of the Project, within three months
after the end of the fiscal year, including a detailed assessment of the
irrigation system performance as well as recommendations and measures
proposed to improve its 0&M.

H. Project Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation

28. A socioeconomic benchmark survey was prepared by local
consultants during the feasibility study for the Project in March 1990.
The survey will be updated by DOl towards completion of the Project. To
monitor economic and technical performance after Project completion, the
CFC will keep records of irrigation and agricultural operations and
systems performance. DOl will carry out a detailed annual assessment of
the irrigation system's performance. A report on these findings, together
with recommendations for possible improvements in O&M and possible
selective assistance by DOl, will be submitted to and discussed with the
CFA. A copy of the report will be submitted to the Bank for information.

I. Operation and Maintenance

29.	
Upon completion of the works, the Central Farmers Association
(CFA) will assume the full 0&M responsibility, except for emergency
repairs that are beyond its capability to execute. 	
In the latter
situation, DOl will carry out the repairs under the same cost-sharing
arrangements as applied for the construction of the Project. The
Department of Roads (DOR) will take over the responsibility for the O&M
of the East-West Feeder road after its completion while the farmers will
be responsible for 0&M of the North-South Service Road. After completion
of the Project, the district DOl staff will remain associated with the
Project in an advisory function to CFA. The district irrigation engineer
together with representatives of the CFA will carry out quarterly
inspections of the Project. If during such inspection 0&M deficiencies
are observed, DOl will direct the CFA to remedy them and will provide
technical expertise if required.

J.	

Imp lementation Schedule

30. The Project will be implemented over a period of six years,
expected to begin in early 1992 and terminating at the end of 1997.
Construction works will be carried out over a period of four years.

K. Environmental Impact

31.	
The replacement of the existing temporary wooden structures of
the irrigation facilities by permanent ones will have a positive

 10

environmental impact as it will save about 20,000 cubic meters of wood
annually, which is equal to the preservation of 400 ha of mixed forest in
Nepal annually. The economic value of these benefits can be estimated at
$240,000 per annum.

32. Closing of the five existing intakes and of selected river
channels will reduce the risk of river and canal bank erosion and river
capture of farmland by uncontrolled floods. On the basis of historic
data, it is estimated that about 20 ha. of farmland will be saved annually
by the Project. In addition, other non-quantified environmental benefits
will arise, as the preservation of forests will result in a reduction of
soil erosion, which causes downstream siltation and loss of soil
fertility.

L.	

Project Justification and Benefits

33. The quantifiable agricultural benefits of the Project consists
mainly of (i) a modest increase in irrigated area of about 1,000 ha, (ii)
improved yields arising from enhanced water availability, particularly
during the monsoon period, of about 20 per cent on average, and (iii) an
increase in cropping intensity arising from the earlier availability of
water supply from 180 per cent to 219 per cent. At full development the
annual incremental production resulting from the Project is estimated at
$4.7 million at 1991 constant prices. The Project will also reduce the 0&M
requirements of the irrigation system through the replacement of
maintenance-intensive temporary structures by durable masonry and concrete
ones; and through construction of one common intake structure, thus
concentrating future maintenance efforts on one intake and one approach
channel instead of the existing six. The economic internal rate of return
(EIRR) and the financial internal rate of return (FIRR) of the Project has
been estimated at 18.1 per cent and 9.5 per cent, respectively. If the
estimated value of environmental benefits is taken into consideration, the
EIRR goes up to 18.8 per cent.

34. In addition, the Project is expected to contribute to poverty
alleviation for the 4,300 farm households and some 3,000 landless farm
families (Kamaiyas) living in the Project area. Under the Project, the
annual farm income of a typical farm household will increase from NRs
14,970 ($ 350 ) without the Project to NRs 37,360 ($875). The annual income
of a typical Kamaia family will increase from NRs 12,970 ($ 304 ) to NRs
20,840 ($488). On the basis of the distribution of farm sizes, it is
estimated that the proportion of people living below the poverty line (NRs
3,100) in the Project area will decrease from 80 per cent to 20 per cent.

M.	

Project Risks

35. The major risk associated with the Project is that farmers may
not be willing to continue with O&M as a result of the inability of the
Project to fulfill their requirements because of lack of their
participation in Project preparation and implementation. To ensure that

 11

the proposed Project reflects farmers t felt needs, they were consulted on
the required scope of the rehabilitation works during the feasibility
study, during the Government's consultation visit to the Project area and
during the Bank's Fact-Finding and Appraisal Missions. To maintain farmer
participation and involvement during the further stages of Project
implementation, the existing farmer organizations will be incorporated in
the Project organization and will have joint responsibility for
implementation, together with DOl, through their representation in the
Project Management Committee. To enhance farmers' institutional and
technical capabilities, advisory technical assistance will be provided in
parallel with the Project (see para. 40).

N.	

Policy Aspects

1. Farmers' Participation

36.
Lack of farmers participation in water management was the main
reason of the low performance of irrigation projects in Nepal. The
proposed Project has addressed directly this issue by seeking farmers
participation since the early stage of Project preparation and later
during design and implementation. The aim of this strategy is to develop
among the farmers a sense of ownership of the irrigation facilities. In
the feasibility study stage, farmers were already consulted on the
magnitude of assistance needed, and the proposed Project fully reflects
their requirements. Participation of the farmers in Project
implementation has been institutionalized, and major decision-making
authority on crucial design and implementation issues has been assigned
to them to ensure that the final Project continues to reflect and meet
their requirements.

37.
To enhance the participation of farmers, they are expected to
contribute towards the construction costs of the subprojects, partly in
cash and mostly in the form of labor. The Government has agreed that
total farmers' contribution to the irrigation component of the Project
should be in accordance with the cost-sharing arrangements presently
applied for the rehabilitation of small- and medium-scale FMISs. For a
total Project area of 13,000 ha, the per hectare development cost for
irrigation amounts to NRs 32,200 ($754). On the basis of these unit
costs, the farmers' contribution will be NRs 3,000 per ha (about 9.3 per
cent of the construction cost), to be paid in cash or in kind or a
combination thereof. The Government has emphasized that enhanced farmer
participation will remain an essential policy aim in the irrigation
subsector.

2. Cost Recovery

38.
In the past, Water User Organizations have been able to
effectively collect contributions from farmers participating in FMISs to
meet O&M costs. One of the most important concerns of the Bank has been
to retain this tradition by reinforcing the institutional capabilities of

 12

the farmer associations in charge of collecting fees and managing the
necessary repairs to the schemes. The achievement of complete autonomy
by the farmer associations in implementing and financing 0&M works is one
of the main aims of the Project. In accordance with the principle of
leaving the management of the irrigation facilities to the farmers, the
CFA will be responsible for providing an adequate plan of cost recovery
for 0&M works before the start of construction works.

0.	

Specific Assurances

39.	
the following specific assurances to the Bank:

In addition to the standard covenants, the Government has given

(i)

Project Conce p t. The Government will ensure that the
following policies are observed in the construction and
rehabilitation of Project facilities: (a) participation of
farmer beneficiaries in the identification, design,
construction, and O&M of new irrigation facilities; and (b)
sharing of construction cost between the Government and the
farmer beneficiaries;

(ii)

(iii)

(iv)

(v)

Joint Project Management Committee. The Government will
ensure that a joint PMC will be established in which the
responsibility for Project implementation will be shared with
representatives of concerned farmers in the Project area;

Farmers' Contribution to Construction Cost. The Government
will ensure that beneficiary farmers contribute to the
construction cost in accordance with the cost-sharing
arrangements applied for the rehabilitation of small- and
medium- scale FMISs;

Central Farmers Association. The Government will ensure that
all necessary actions will be taken to assist the existing
FMISs to establish or constitute themselves into a unified
organization, the new CFA. Registration of the CFA under the
Association Registration Act, 2034 will be a condition for
loan effectiveness;

Agreement Between DOl and CFA. The Government will ensure
that, prior to the commencement of Project preparatory
activities, a written agreement between the Executing Agency
and the CFA has been executed covering the following subjects:
(i) acceptability by the farmers of the broad scope of the
Project; (ii) future allocation of the irrigation flow in the
Budi Kulo main canal to the branch canals in the Project area;
(iii) draft organizational setup and resource mobilization
(labor and cash) for 0&M of the new irrigation facilities,
including the annual excavation of the approach canal; (iv)
farmers' preparedness to participate actively in Project

 13

implementation and to contribute their share to the
construction cost in labor and/or cash; and (v) procedures
for handing over and subsequent O&M of the completed
irrigation facilities;

(vi)

Operation and Maintenance. The Government will ensure that,
upon completion and handing over of the works, the CFA will
assume full O&M responsibility for the irrigation facilities.
In case of emergencies requiring repairs beyond the
capabilities of the CFA, the repairs will be carried out by
the Executing Agency in accordance with the same cost-sharing
arrangements as applied for the construction of the works.
After completion of the Project, the Executing Agency will
carry out quarterly inspections of the irrigation facilities
and provide the necessary assistance if deemed so as a result
of the inspections;

(vii)

(viii)

(ix)

Project Benefit Monitoring and Evaluation. The Government
will ensure that, after completion of the Project, the
Executing Agency will carry out annual inspections of the
irrigation system's performance and that the CFC will keep
records of irrigation and agricultural operations and system
performance to monitor the economic and technical performance
of Project facilities;

Environmental Imp act. To safeguard against any possible
adverse effect on the environment, the Government will ensure
that, in the implementation of the Project, the Bank's
Environmental Guidelines for Irrigation Projects. Land
Clearance and Watershed Develo pment will be observed; and

Agricultural Support Services. The Government will ensure
that the farmers in the Project area will have timely access
to the necessary agricultural support services and credit to
enable them to take full advantage of the increased potential
for crop production as a result of the facilities to be
improved under the Project.

P. Technical Assistance

40. The Government has requested the  Bank to finance an advisory
technical assistance to assist  in establishing the institutional base for
farmers' effective participation in Project implementation, and to
strengthen the institutional base and technical capabilities of the
farmers' organizations to continue 06CM after Project completion. It  is
envisaged that about 12 man-months of the services of international
consultants in the field of institutional development/community irrigation
development will be needed. In addition, about 100 man-months of domestic
consultant	
institutional
development/administration and rural sociology/community irrigation

required	

services	

will	

for	

be	

 14

development.	
The consultants will be engaged in accordance with the
Bank's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. The total cost of the
technical assistance is estimated to be $750,000, of which $250,000 is the
foreign exchange cost. It is proposed that the Bank finance the entire
foreign exchange cost and a part of the local currency cost, for a total
amount of $650,000, from the Bank's Technical Assistance Special Fund.
The Government will provide the remaining local currency cost from its own
funds.

IV. LEGAL INSTRUMENTS AND AUTHORITY

41.
of Nepal and the Bank is circulated herewith.

The draft Loan Agreement (Special Operations) between the Kingdom

42.
dated 7 December 1982 are incorporated in the draft Loan Agreement.

The provisions of the Bank's Special Operations Loan Regulations

The Kingdom of Nepal is empowered under its laws to borrow from
43.
the Bank, and the Department of Irrigation is authorized to implement the
Project.

44.
Articles of Agreement of the Bank.

I am satisfied that the proposed Loan would comply with the

V. RECOMMENDATION

I recommend that the Board approve the proposed loan to the
45.
Kingdom of Nepal for the Rajapur Irrigation Rehabilitation Project in an
amount in various currencies equivalent to Twelve Million One Hundred
Fifty-Two Thousand Special Drawing Rights (SDR 12.152 million) with a
service charge at the rate of one per cent (1%) per annum and carrying
such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with
those set forth in the draft Agreement presented to the Board.

46.
I also recommend that the Board approve the proposed technical
assistance to the Government of Nepal for institutional support for
Project implementation in an amount not exceeding the equivalent of
$650,000 to be financed on a grant basis from the Bank's Technical
Assistance Special Fund.

8 October 1991

KIMIMASA TARUMIZU
President
